original_summary: Prior to the current update it appeared there was some evidence that cranberry juice may decrease the number of symptomatic UTIs over a 12 month period, particularly for women with recurrent UTIs. The addition of 14 further studies suggests that cranberry juice is less effective than previously indicated. Although some of small studies demonstrated a small benefit for women with recurrent UTIs, there were no statistically significant differences when the results of a much larger study were included. Cranberry products were not significantly different to antibiotics for preventing UTIs in three small studies. Given the large number of dropouts/withdrawals from studies (mainly attributed to the acceptability of consuming cranberry products particularly juice, over long periods), and the evidence that the benefit for preventing UTI is small, cranberry juice cannot currently be recommended for the prevention of UTIs. Other preparations (such as powders) need to be quantified using standardised methods to ensure the potency, and contain enough of the 'active' ingredient, before being evaluated in clinical studies or recommended for use.

original_summary:
Medication treatments can be effective in paediatric anxiety disorders, acting to reduce core symptoms, and should be considered as part of the treatment of these disorders. The greatest number of trials showing efficacy to date have assessed the SSRIs in treating paediatric OCD.
There is no clear evidence to show that any particular class of medication is more effective or better tolerated than any other. As quantitative data was only available for the SSRIs and venlafaxine the routine use of benzodiazepines cannot be recommended, especially given concerns of dependency and treatment -related emergent adverse events associated with this class of drugs. 

Future RCTs could help identify potential clinical moderators of treatment efficacy. Studies of the long-term efficacy of medication treatment, optimal dosage, as well as direct comparisons of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy are also warranted.

Short-term teriflunomide, 7 or 14 mg alone or with add-on IFN-β, was safe for patients with relapsing MS. Both teriflunomide 7 and 14 mg alone had potential benefits for patients with relapsing forms of MS. We are waiting for the publication of ongoing trials. RCTs with high methodological quality and longer periods of observation are needed to assess safety, disability progression, neuroprotection and quality of life.

original_summary:
One study suggested that topical ketanserin is more effective than clioquinol cream or zinc paste. Topical phenytoin (two studies) may be more effective than saline dressing regarding ulcer healing. For the other dressings the results were equivocal. Canvas shoes were a little better than PVC-boots, but not significantly, and the effect of double rocker shoes compared to below-knee plasters was no different in promoting the healing of ulcers. No side effects were documented.
There is a lack of high quality research in the field of ulcer prevention and treatment in leprosy. New trials should follow the current standards for design and reporting of randomised controlled trials.

The four studies discussed the use of topical treatments for promoting the healing of trophic ulcers in leprosy patients.

The first study compared the effects of topical phenytoin powder and normal saline on trophic leprosy ulcers. The study found that healthy granulation tissue appeared earlier, and the mean percentage of ulcer volume reduction was greater in the phenytoin group compared to the control group.

The second study evaluated and compared two strengths of topical phenytoin sodium suspension (2% and 4%) with normal saline in the healing of acute trophic ulcers in leprosy patients. Overall, the studies suggest that topical treatments, including phenytoin, ketanserin, and zinc oxide tape, may be effective in promoting the healing of trophic ulcers in leprosy patients. The article discusses the effectiveness of various medications in reducing impulsive aggression in individuals with psychiatric disorders. Six studies were conducted, each using a different medication, and all were double-blind, placebo-controlled trials. The studies included a total of 254 patients with an Axis I psychiatric disorder and comorbid alcohol dependence, 94 cocaine-abusing methadone patients with and without antisocial personality disorder, and 216 male alcoholic patients subtyped by comorbid psychiatric disorder(s).

The results of the studies showed that phenytoin, naltrexone, and divalproex were effective in reducing impulsive aggression, but the combination of disulfiram and naltrexone did not provide an advantage. The studies suggest that certain medications can be effective in controlling impulsive aggression in individuals with psychiatric disorders, and that antisocial personality disorder may be a factor to consider when treating patients with substance use disorders. original_summary: Despite concerns surrounding the use of opioids for long-term management of chronic LBP, there remain few high-quality trials assessing their efficacy. The trials in this review, although achieving high internal validity scores, were characterized by a lack of generalizability, inadequate description of study populations, poor intention-to treat analyses, and limited interpretation of functional improvement. Based on our results, the benefits of opioids in clinical practice for the long-term management of chronic LBP remain questionable. Therefore, further high-quality studies that more closely simulate clinical practice are needed to assess the usefulness, and potential risks, of opioids for individuals with chronic LBP.

original_summary: T-tube drainage appeared to result in significantly longer operating time and hospital stay compared with primary closure without any apparent evidence of benefit on clinically important outcomes after open common bile duct exploration. Based on the currently available evidence, there is no justification for the routine use of T-tube drainage after open common bile duct exploration in patients with common bile duct stones. T-tube drainage should not be used outside well designed randomised clinical trials. More randomised trials comparing the effects of T-tube drainage versus primary closure after open common bile duct exploration may be needed. Such trials should be conducted with low risk of bias and assessing the long-term beneficial and harmful effects of T-tube drainage, including long-term complications such as bile stricture and recurrence of common bile duct stones.

The study also found that the postoperative stay was significantly prolonged in the T-tube group, and that T-tube drainage of the bile continued for a longer period than wound drainage in the primary closure group. Overall, the evidence suggests that infliximab may be effective in the treatment of ulcerative colitis, particularly in patients with moderate-to-severe active disease who have not responded to conventional treatment. A pilot dose-finding study showed promise, with a statistically significant reduction in endpoint Y-MRS change scores for the higher dose (512 mg/day) topiramate treatment group compared to placebo. Adverse effects include attention and memory problems, fatigue, sedation, paraesthesias, nausea, anorexia, and word-finding difficulty. Weight loss may also occur. While the results are promising, more definitive controlled data are needed to fully evaluate the efficacy of topiramate in treating bipolar disorder, both in the acute and continuation phases, and as monotherapy or combination treatment.

original_summary:
Improvement in control of maternal blood pressure with use of beta-blockers would be worthwhile only if it were reflected in substantive benefits for mother and/or baby, and none have been clearly demonstrated. The effect of beta-blockers on perinatal outcome is uncertain; the worrying trend to an increase in SGA infants is partly dependent on one small outlying trial. Large randomised trials are needed to determine whether antihypertensive therapy in general (rather than beta-blocker therapy specifically) results in greater benefit than risk, for treatment of mild-moderate pregnancy hypertension. If so, then it would be appropriate to consider which antihypertensive is best, and beta-blockers should be evaluated.
[Note: the seventeen reports in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the review once assessed.]

The study found that FTC-TDF significantly reduced the incidence of HIV infection by 44% compared to placebo, with a 51% detection rate of the study drug in seronegative subjects and a 9% detection rate in HIV-infected subjects. Nausea was more common in the FTC-TDF group during the first 4 weeks, but the two groups had similar rates of serious adverse events. original_summary: Community-based interventions and antenatal contraceptive counselling improved uptake of copper IUD contraception. Since the copper IUD is one of the most effective reversible contraceptive methods, primary care and family planning and practitioners could consider adopting these interventions. Although our review suggests these interventions are clinically effective, a cost-benefit analysis may be required to evaluate applicability.
generated_summary:
A study was conducted to determine the impact of counseling and educational leaflets on contraceptive practices among couples. The study involved 600 women who were randomly divided into two groups: an intervention group that received counseling and educational leaflets, and a control group that did not receive any formal contraceptive advice. The results showed that there was a significant increase in contraceptive uptake among women in the intervention group, with a shift towards more reliable methods. In contrast, the control group had a lower rate of contraceptive use, with a higher proportion of women using less reliable methods. The study concluded that providing counseling and educational leaflets can effectively promote contraceptive use among couples.

Another study evaluated the effectiveness of a personalized counseling on contraceptive acceptability and use among postabortion women in Brazil. The results showed that the strategy of individualized contraceptive counseling increased the acceptance and use of contraceptive methods, and improved the adequate use of the methods.

A controlled field trial study in Iran evaluated the effects of community-based distribution (CBD) on contraceptive usage. The results showed that using CBD increased the level of contraceptive knowledge, enhanced correct contraceptive choice by couples, improved contraceptive usage, and improved contraceptive continuation rates.

A randomized controlled trial in Syria assessed the effect of postnatal home visits on maternal postpartum morbidities, infant morbidity, uptake of postpartum care, use of contraceptive methods, and selected neonatal health practices. The results showed that postnatal home visits significantly increased exclusive breastfeeding, but did not affect other outcomes.

Finally, a study investigated the impact of antenatal counseling on couples' knowledge and practice of contraception. The results showed that counseling sessions improved the couples' knowledge and practice of contraception, and involving husbands in family planning counselling sessions led to joint decisions being made and encouraged women's use of contraception. The majority of couples retained most of the information given, and the study recommended integrating family planning counselling into antenatal care in all facilities and involving the husband.

Overall, these studies suggest that providing counseling and educational resources, using personalized approaches, and involving community-based distribution can effectively promote contraceptive use and improve reproductive health outcomes.

original_summary: Although antibiotic treatment is effective for the cure of urinary tract infections, there are insufficient data to recommend any specific drug regimen for treatment of symptomatic urinary tract infections during pregnancy. All the antibiotics studied were shown to be very effective in decreasing the incidence of the different outcomes. Complications were very rare. All included trials had very small sample sizes to reliably detect important differences between treatments. Future studies should evaluate the most promising antibiotics, in terms of class, timing, dose, acceptability, maternal and neonatal outcomes and costs.
generated_summary:
The article discusses the treatment and management of urinary tract infections (UTIs) and pyelonephritis during pregnancy. The authors highlight the importance of early diagnosis and treatment to prevent complications and ensure a positive pregnancy outcome.

One study compared the efficacy of a single dose of fosfomycin trometamol with a 3-day course of ceftibuten in treating acute cystitis in pregnant women. The results showed that both regimens were effective, with a clinical cure rate of 95.2% for fosfomycin trometamol and 90.0% for ceftibuten. However, the study also noted that long-term chemoprophylaxis may be necessary in patients with recurrent UTIs or following acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy.

Another study compared the efficacy and safety of cefuroxime and cephradine in treating acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy. The results showed that cefuroxime was more effective and better tolerated than cephradine, with a clinical cure rate of 78.8% compared to 59.2%. Additionally, cefuroxime had a lower rate of resistance to uropathogens.

A third study evaluated the efficacy of a therapeutic course of intravenous antibiotics followed by oral antibiotics in preventing recurrent urinary tract infections. The results showed that completion of a 10-day course of oral nitrofurantoin did not significantly reduce the risk of recurrent pyelonephritis immediately post-parenteral treatment.

A fourth study compared the effectiveness of three antibiotic regimens for the treatment of acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy. The results showed that there were no significant differences in clinical response or birth outcomes among subjects treated with ampicillin and gentamicin, cefazolin, or ceftriaxone.

Finally, a fifth study compared outpatient and inpatient management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy beyond 24 weeks' gestation. The results showed that there were no significant differences in clinical responses or birth outcomes between inpatients and outpatients treated for acute pyelonephritis, but 30% of outpatients were unable to complete their assigned protocols.

Overall, the studies suggest that early diagnosis and treatment of UTIs and pyelonephritis during pregnancy are crucial to prevent complications and ensure a positive pregnancy outcome. The choice of antibiotic regimen and management strategy should be individualized based on the severity and duration of symptoms, the patient's medical history, and other factors.

original_summary: There is insufficient evidence to determine possible advantages or disadvantages of immediate, immediate-delayed or delayed implants, therefore these preliminary conclusions are based on few underpowered trials often judged to be at high risk of bias. There is a suggestion that immediate and immediate-delayed implants may be at higher risks of implant failures and complications than delayed implants on the other hand the aesthetic outcome might be better when placing implants just after teeth extraction. There is not enough reliable evidence supporting or refuting the need for augmentation procedures at immediate implants placed in fresh extraction sockets or whether any of the augmentation techniques is superior to the others.
generated_summary:
This study compared the effects of immediate versus delayed placement of titanium dental implants with acid-etched surfaces (Osseotite) in extraction sockets, and evaluated the crestal bone changes and soft tissue response. Forty-six patients were randomly allocated to the immediate or delayed group, and received one implant each in the maxilla or mandible. The results showed that both groups had a high survival rate (91% and 96%, respectively), and the reduction in parallel width, perpendicular width, and depth of the largest defect was statistically significant over time in both groups. However, the immediate group had a higher degree of bone healing in infrabony defects than in dehiscence-type defects, and 70% of the 3-wall infrabony defects with a parallel width of up to 5 mm, a depth of maximum 4 mm, and a perpendicular width of maximum 2 mm had a capacity of spontaneous healing within a period of 3 months.

The study also compared the clinical success of immediately placed implants in chronic periapical infected sites. Fifty patients were included in the study, with 25 patients receiving immediately placed Frialit-2 Synchro implants and 25 patients receiving implants placed after a 3-month healing period. The results showed that the survival rate was 92% for the immediately placed implants and 100% for the delayed implants, and there were no significant differences in mean implant stability quotient values, gingival aesthetics, radiographic bone loss, and microbiologic characteristics of periapical lesions between the two groups.

Another study compared the immediate restoration of single implants in the esthetic zones performed on implants placed immediately after tooth extraction or 8 weeks later. Sixteen patients were treated with tapered effect (TE) implants, and the results showed that there were no statistically significant differences in marginal bone resorption, papilla index, and position of the mucosal margin between the two groups. The implant stability quotient values were significant at the moment of implant placement but not at the moment of delivery of the definitive restoration.

A study compared the efficacy of combinations of membranes and autogenous bone grafts at immediate implants. Sixty-two patients received an immediate implant for a single tooth replacement, and the results showed that all groups showed significant reduction in vertical defect height, horizontal defect depth, and horizontal defect width. However, there were no significant differences between groups in HDW reduction, and membrane-treated groups showed the greatest reduction in HDW. In the presence of dehiscence defects of the labial plate, HDW reduction of 66.6% was achieved with membrane use compared to 37.7% without membranes.

A study evaluated the hard and soft tissue response to immediate versus delayed implant placement after tooth removal, with immediate provisionalization, in maxillary anterior sites. Seventy-six patients were randomized into treatment groups, and the results showed that there were no significant differences between groups in implant integration or crestal interdental bone movement. However, the bone level on the implants did move from the baseline levels during the first 6 months but not thereafter, and there was a significant difference in the position of the facial gingival margin between the immediate and delayed groups.

Finally, a study evaluated healing of marginal defects in immediate transmucosal implants grafted with anorganic bovine bone, and assessed mucosal and radiographic outcomes 3-4 years following restoration. Thirty immediate transmucosal implants were placed in maxillary anterior extraction sites, and the results showed that BioOss significantly reduced horizontal resorption of buccal bone. However, there was a risk of mucosal recession and adverse soft tissue esthetics with immediate implant placement, and this risk may be reduced by avoiding a buccal position of the implant in the extraction socket.

original_summary: Carbamazepine is effective in chronic neuropathic pain, with caveats. No trial was longer than four weeks, of good reporting quality, using outcomes equivalent to at least moderate clinical benefit. In these circumstances, caution is needed in interpretation, and meaningful comparison with other interventions is not possible.
generated_summary: A double-blind, randomized study compared the efficacy and tolerability of prednisolone and carbamazepine in treating early, severe painful herpes zoster in 40 patients over 50 years old. The study found that prednisolone significantly reduced the incidence and duration of post-herpetic neuralgia compared to carbamazepine. In a separate double-blind study, tizanidine was compared to carbamazepine in managing trigeminal neuralgia. Tizanidine was well-tolerated, but its effects were inferior to those of carbamazepine. Another double-blind, crossover study compared the combination of nortriptyline-fluphenazine (NF) and carbamazepine (CMZ) in treating severe, distal, symmetrical, predominantly sensitive diabetic polyneuropathy (DPN). Both therapies produced significant improvements in pain and paresthesia, but no statistically significant differences were observed between the two therapies. A double-blind, 3-phase, cross-over, placebo-controlled trial found that amitriptyline significantly reduced pain in patients with central post-stroke pain (CPSP) compared to placebo, while carbamazepine did not produce significant pain relief. In a double-blind cross-over study, tocainide and carbamazepine were alternatively given to 12 patients with trigeminal neuralgia, and both drugs showed similar analgesic effects. Finally, a double-blind crossover trial compared pimozide and carbamazepine in 48 patients with trigeminal neuralgia who were refractory to medical therapy. Pimozide treatment produced greater reduction in trigeminal neuralgia symptoms than carbamazepine treatment.
